meta.content: Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) imagery is considered the best approach to acquire high-resolution data over a large area in a short time, such as in the case of coastal wetlands comprising small-sized patches of perennial plants. However, to the best of our knowledge, no previous studies have used UAV imagery to quantitatively estimate blue carbon in coastal wetlands. Therefore, this study aimed to estimate the area-wide carbon stocks accumulated in halophyte habitats through the case studies of the southern coastal wetlands in South Korea using UAV imagery. Accordingly, object-based image analysis was used to identify the spatial distribution of major halophytes based on the spectral reflectance derived from multispectral UAV images. Elemental analysis (EA) was performed to estimate the content of organic carbon accumulated in individual halophytes, and the halophyte communities identified in the case study area were confirmed to have accumulated 20.80 MgC of blue carbon. These results demonstrate that applying EA to UAV images can be an innovative method to solve the spatial uncertainty encountered in the monitoring of blue carbon in existing field-based surveys and traditional remote sensing.

div.p:
Unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) imagery is considered the best approach to acquire high-resolution data over a large area in a short time, such as in the case of coastal wetlands comprising small-sized patches of perennial plants. However, t
o the best of our knowledge,
no previous studies have used UAV imagery to quantitatively estimate blue carbon in coastal wetlands. Therefore, this study aimed to estimate the area-wide carbon stocks accumulated in halophyte habitats through the case studies of the
southern coastal wetlands in South Korea
using
UAV imagery. Accordingly,
object-based image analysis was used to identify the spatial distribution of major halophytes based on the spectral reflectance derived from multispectral UAV images. Elemental analysis (EA) was performed to estimate the content of organic carbon accumulated in individual halophytes, and the halophyte communities identified in the case study area were confirmed to have accumulated 20.80 MgC of blue carbon. These results demonstrate that applying EA to UAV images can be an innovative method to solve the spatial uncertainty encountered in the monitoring of blue carbon in existing field-based surveys and traditional remote sensing.

Conducting a field survey in the upper intertidal zone, where halophytes are primarily distributed, is difficult because fine-grained wet soil predominates, and sometimes seawater overflows. Remote sensing is a technology that enables mapping without direct access to the wetlands using various sensors and allows the investigation of inaccessible area-wide targets. Previous studies have used satellite imageries and manned aircraft images to investigate the spatial distribution of coastal wetlands in a non-destructive approach (Wu et al.
2017
). Studies regarding the measurement of carbon stock accumulated in area-wide targets using GHG observation satellites, such as Greenhouse Gases Observing Satellite (GOSAT), and Orbiting Carbon Observatory (OCO-2), have been conducted (Hwang and Um
2016
; Park et al.
2018
,
2017
; Hwang and Um
2016a
; Hwang and Um
2016b
; Matloob et al.
2021a
; Matloob et al.
2021b
). Satellite imagery has limitations in providing information regarding local targets, such as species composition in coastal wetlands, because of the coarse spatial resolution. In the case of aerial photographs captured via manned pilots, securing high-resolution images for monitoring local specific spatial objects, such as halophytes in tidal flats, is difficult because low-altitude flights are not allowed to ensure pilot safety.

On the contrary, unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) imagery can secure a sub-centimeter pixel resolution similar to field surveys without an onboard pilot shooting directly near the salt marsh habitat. UAV imagery has already been used to estimate the halophyte habitat in coastal wetlands (Doughty and Cavanaugh
2019
; Samiappan et al.
2017
). However, to the best of our knowledge, no previous studies have calculated the amount of carbon storage for halophyte communities classified using UAV images. This study aims to explore the quantity of blue carbon accumulated in individual vegetation areas via UAV imagery from an area-wide perspective. Overcoming the limitations of previous studies using field surveys, satellite images, and manned aircraft images, the results of this work provide a piece of realistic evidence to build a blue carbon inventory of coastal wetlands in the IPCC Tier 3 dimension.

Orfeo ToolBox (OTB, version 7.0) is an open-source project that processes remote sensing images; it can be operated by interlocking with the open-source GIS software QGIS (version 3.4). OTB provides a function to classify UAV images and detailed procedures necessary to verify classification results. OTB was utilized to classify the halophyte communities in the study area. In processing UAV imagery, object-based image analysis (OBIA) is commonly implemented using identical pixel values instead of the individual pixel values themselves because the vegetation can have the same pixel values among diverse species. In this study, the produced orthophoto was subjected to OBIA using the range of pixel values that is more indicative for classifying the different species of vegetation.

A large-scale mean-shift (LSMS) is a segmentation algorithm that processes a large number of high-resolution images in a tile-wise manner in one pass. Theoretically, LSMS yields the same segmentation results when each image is individually processed (Michel et al.,
2014
). Support vector machine (SVM) is a learning theory, first proposed by Vapnik in 1995, based on an algorithm that reduces generalization errors via structural risk minimization rather than empirical risk minimization employed in the existing statistical theory. One of the advantages of SVM is that it provides fairly good classification results even with a small number of samples (Foody and Mathur
2006
; Tzotsos and Argialas
2008
). LSMS was implemented during OBIA, and SVM was applied for imagery classification.

Halophytes are distributed in high-tide, low-tide, and intertidal zones of the tidal flat by adapting to the environment with high salt concentration, as shown in Fig.
5
. As their habitat moves from the top to the bottom of the tidal flat, the density of vegetation communities decreases and the soil layers comprising gravel and clay are distributed. The representative vegetation species in the study area form eight different communities (
Limonium tetragonum
,
Carex scabrifolia
,
Phragmites communis
,
Suaeda japonica
,
Zoysia sinica
,
Triglochin maritimum
,
Artemisia fukudo
, and
Suaeda maritima
) according to the geographic characteristics of the wetland. For example,
Suaeda japonica
and
Triglochin maritimum
form communities where the seawater directly flows into the high tide, whereas
Limonium tetragonum
and
Suaeda japonica
are primarily distributed in areas close to the land, which are not submerged in seawater.
Phragmites communis
are distributed at diverse habitat conditions, from the areas where seawater directly infiltrates, to the areas where freshwater from nearby rivers or streams flow. The soil comprises gravel, sand, silt, and clay. The composition of soil samples indicates that sand and gravel account for a large proportion of the soil (more than 50% of the composition), whereas silt and clay exhibit a relatively sparse distribution. A training dataset for image classification was created using the field information collected via random sampling, 70% of which was used to classify orthoimages as training data, and the remaining 30% was used to verify classified output (Fig.
6

div.p:
In the terrestrial biomass of individual halophyte plants, leaf and stem parts are important parameters for determining photosynthesis, which governs atmospheric CO
2
absorption. UAVs freely control flight altitude and camera exposure (i.e., shutter and aperture) that can obtain images with a spatial resolution sufficient in estimating carbon accumulated in sub-centimeter-sized patches of halophyte community. UAV images facilitate access to the blue carbon ecosystem, based on a wide range of object identifications in halophyte colonies, which has not been detected from the satellite and manned aerial images. This study provided tangible evidence that the terrestrial biomass of herbaceous salivary plants identified at a sub-centimeter pixel can be linked to organic carbon analysis using elemental analyzers. The halophyte communities that have been qualitatively classified in the field can be supplemented in an optimal manner in a short time by UAV surveys based on high location accuracy and accessibility. Thus, this study provides differentiated area-wide information from the field investigation by identifying the characteristics of fluid carbon fixation of ground-based biomass in conjunction with EA methods. The UAV images to estimate the carbon sequestered in the blue carbon ecosystem can sufficiently comply with MRV requirements for blue carbon, although UAV is a cheaper approach to acquire data than other remote sensing platforms. UAV imaging can be introduced as a standardized procedure for estimating blue carbon storage in combination with EA. Ultimately, this study found that UAV technology can contribute significantly to producing world-wide GHG inventory for sub-centimeter-level targets such as blue carbon.

This study describes the first attempt to generate a blue carbon map that applies the carbon conversion factor derived from the EA to the classified images. The carbon conversion factor analyzed in samples of major salty plants ranged from 34.2% to 45.5%, and the total amount of carbon accumulated in the study area (1.34 ha) was 20.8 MgC for vegetation. The estimation of blue carbon accumulated in salt plants via high-resolution imagery was provided as an alternative to a traditional field survey. Moreover, this study demonstrates that UAV imagery can be used to address the uncertainty faced in the existing field-based approaches, satellite imagery, or manned aerial photography.
